comments:
This problem came up after I migrated to M7, and has continued in M8.  

Normally with Eclipse 3.x, if I check out a project from CVS - then work with it, like if I begin editing a 
.java file in the eclipse editor, Eclipse used to mark it editable and then allow me to edit it.  But now 
after M7, I would be blocked from editing the file, and I would have to do one of a few things which 
were really annoying.

1. Pick Team > Edit to have eclipse attempt ot make it editable, which would result in a "Errors in 
deleting resources" message.  Then I would have to pick Properties, then un-check the Read-Only 
attribute and then I finally can edit it. 

OR

1. Go to terminal and type 'chflags -R nouchg .' in the workspace directory, to mark the files not read-
only and then eclipse will allow me to edit the files normally.  

However problem with the above solutions is that as soon as I refresh from CVS, or do a replace file 
from CVS or anything (or set up a new workspace), those files would be read-only again, and I'd run 
into the same problems again.  My co-worker here also uses Eclipse on his Powerbook and has been 
experiencing the same problems.   Another co-worker with a PC does not have this problem.

Just wondering if anything was changed w/ how Eclipse handles marking files read-only, and vice versa 
between M7 and earlier versions, that might have brought about this regression.  Everything worked 
fine prior to M7 in our development environment.  (Note, we did skip M5, M6, I believe).  I am willing to 
try out earlier milestones or do tests on my computer to give additional information, if any of you 
request it.

This works on Windows. Can you set the read-only status of a file through the 
Properties dialog in Eclipse?

Like I said in my original comment, a co-worker using a PC does not see this problem.  

And I also mentioned in my original comment that unsetting the Read-Only flag in Properties window 
does allow me to edit it, but as soon as that file is checked in, or if I do a 'replace from HEAD' - the file 
again exhibits the same problems.

Sorry, I'm not having one of my better days. Is there anything in the log file 
(the contents of the log can be viewed using the Error Log view)? It sounds 
like it could be related to previous project state. Have you tried working 
with a project that has been checkout out from scratch?

Ok, I wasn't able to find this Error Log you referred to - if u can tell me where to find this, I will look at 
it.

I also tried to reproduce this problem with the latest integration build from eclipse.org and a clean 
project checkout from cvs.. same problems occured.

 I did open up a tail console on the .log file in the workspace directory and then I did these steps.

1. Selected file to be edited.  Hit return to try to add a new line.  Nothing happend.
2. Right-click file and selected Team > Edit
3. Progress view came up, no errors or problems reported.
4. Tried to add new lines.  Still couldnt.
5. Right-click file and selected Team > Edit again
6. Got a prompt that someone was 'editing' the file (which was my host information)
7. Went ahead and edited anyway
8. Got a progress bar again (something to do w/ setting cvs properties, didnt see, went by too fast)
9. Error popup with 'Problems encountered while deleting resources'

Here's the stack trace that came up in the log console.

The error is being thrown because 
file "/Users/timwork/CodeCentral/xxxx/com.xx.xx.xx.xx/src/com/xx/xx/
module/xx/xx/CVS/Base/XXXXX.java" could not be deleted. Unfortunately, we are 
just using the return code from the java.io.File#delete() method which just 
returns a boolean indicating success or failure. What VM are you using? Do you 
get the same behavior with other VMs?

With OSX, there is just one VM (apple supplied).  Here's the simple output.

lust:~ timwork$ java -version
java version "1.4.2_03"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_03-117.1)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-34, mixed mode)

Yes, it seems to be that the problem is w/ deleting the resource in the CVS folder - and this problem 
did not exist for me prior to M7.  So it probably appears to me that it could be one of two things.. 
either that Apple changed something in how the VM handles files, but I find this unlikely because I ran 
across this problem almost immediately after upgrading to M7.  And its possible apple released an Java 
update at about the same time, but I cannot say with certainity either way, since it was a while ago.

I'm looking at the file that it's attempting to delete (same path as the one specified in the stack trace).  
Which appears to be read-only.  And its also interesting that this is a file within CVS/Base - which 
means is it a file that eclipse is creating with it's own CVS implementation?  Or is eclipse simply using 
the CVS implementation provided by OS X?  I do not know those details.

-r--r--r--  1 timwork  timwork  7615  6 May 17:09 Xxxxx.java

So, perhaps this is not what's supposed to  be happening.  Shouldnt this file be writeable as well, so 
that it can be deleted by Eclipse?  Is it possible that theres a bug occuring when Eclipse is creating 
those CVS files and setting them as read-only, instead of being read-writeable?

I also took a look at the actual .java file (not the one in the CVS working directory):

-r--r--r--   1 timwork  timwork   7615  6 May 17:09 Xxxxx.java

After selecting Properties, and unchecking the read-only box, it changes to this:

-rw-r--r--   1 timwork  timwork   7615  6 May 17:09 AuthenticationAction.java

Another thing I've noted just now is that when I check those files out from CVS, they appear in OS X's 
finder with "locked" icons next to each file.   I am quite certain this was not happening prior to M7. 

Getting information on the file, and un-locking the file does not modify the attributes that I pasted in 
above.  So this bit/flag/whatever must be being set somewhere else.  It would seem to me that 
something has changed with how Eclipse is creating the CVS files and source files when getting them 
from CVS, and it manifests itself as a problem with how Eclipse is attempting to edit them.

Forgot to Xxxx out the AuthenticationAction.java filename on the last example, so it's really not that 
the filename itself actually changed.

I looked at the code and we do copy the file before clearing the read-only 
bit. Perhaps the bit is copied on the Mac but not on Windows. I will update 
the code to clear the read-only bit before deleting.

I've released the change to HEAD. It will be in next weeks integration build 
and in M9.
Thanks.  I'll check the integration build when it is released and hopefully it will be all good.

I'm re-opening this bug report because it doesnt seem to be fixed in M9.  

In M9, I no longer get the "errors in deleting resources" message.  However here are the steps I have to 
take if i want to edit a java file.

1. Open java file in editor, attempt to add a new line.  Am not able to because the file is read only.
2. Selected Team > Edit 
3. Two separate "operations in progress" dialogues come up, one after the other, cannot read what they 
are (goes by too quickly).
4. Control returned to editor.  Attempted to add a newline.  Still could not.  
5. Selected Team > Edit 
6. Single "operation in progress" comes up. 
7. Dialogue comes up, saying this resource currently has editors (hostname refers to myself), do i want 
to still send a edit message to the server.
8. clicking yes returns control to the editor.
9. file is now editable.  

I monitored the .log as I was doing all this.  No errors were displayed in the log as far as I can see.

One other addition.  This problem does not seem to affect any file types except .java files.   editing .txt, 
.properties, and .xml files with the basic text editor work just fine.
Copying Andre since he is a Mac guy. Andre, have you seen anything like this?

Could you please check whether you have CVS Watch/Edit mode enabled?
See Windows > Preferences > Team > CVS > Watch/Edit > Configure projects to use...

If you create a new project (that is not shared with a repository) and create a new file within this project, 
is this file editable?

Here are the options I have in the cvs > watch/edit prefs pane.

[ ] configure projects to use watch/edit on checkout (is not checked)

Send a CVS edit notification to server (radio button is on)

Only Prompt if there are other editors (radio button is on)

As for the second question  - I created a new project, and createda HelloWorld.java file w/ the Class 
wizard and then attempted to edit it.  I was able to edit it immediately.

The problem exist on amd 64 version also.  CVS edit is sending notification to the server as "cvs 
editors" show who has the editor on a file, but the file attribute remains read-only on amd 64 linux 
using ext as protocol.

having the same issue as the orignial poster on mac os-x also.

i'll try the same on linux gtk sometime this weekend.

on an additional note, unchecking the read only checkbox in the property window's info section doesn't 
change the file attribute on amd 64 version.

btw, this problem exists on eclipse m9 and RC1.

First of all, let me know if I should open a seperate bug report for this problem as it is possible the 
same behavior displayed on Mac and amd 64 linux could be caused by two different problems.  
But this is what I did as a test.

Testing Environment:
- 3.0 RC1 on Mac OS X 10.3.3 with Apple's JDK 1.4.2
- 3.0 RC1 Linux AMD 64 GTK on Mandrake 10.0 AMD 64 with Blackdown's AMD 64 JDK 1.4.2 RC1
- 3.0 RC1 Linux GTK on Redhat 9.0 with Sun's JDK 1.4.2

Testing Condition:
- Fresh install of eclipse 3.0 RC1 on all three platforms (no existing .metadata)
- after initial launch of eclipse, selected workbench then opened up cvs repository perspective.
- created a new cvs repository location to cvs server using extssh as the protocol.
- check out a module using "check out" context menu option.  (I created a simple cvs module that only 
has eclipse project file, classpath and HellowWorld.java for this testing purpose).
- Open up java perspective
- Open up HelloWorld.java file.
- Hit enter key from the source editor to trigger a cvs edit.

At this point, Mac version and AMD 64 version displayed the same behavior.  In both cases, the cursor 
stays at the position where I hit the enter key (ie didn't create a new line).  And checking on the file's 
readonly attribute from the properties window's info section shows the file is still read only.  

Linux 32 bit GTK version worked as it's supposed to - it created a new line and the file was writable.

As a next step. on Mac and AMD64, I tried explicitly unsetting the readonly attribute from the property 
window's info section by clearing the checkbox.

On Mac version, the check box was cleared and the file became writable.  On AMD64 version however, 
the file still remained read-only, and checking back the property window reveals the file is still read-
only.  So apparently at this point the behavior on two platforms are slightly different.

No log entry was written for these on both platform (although amd 64 version dumps exception 
stacktrace for unzipping quite often, unrelated to this particular problem).

Repeating the same test with ext as protocol produces the same result.

Another issue related to this one is that even though cvs edit was issued successfully while failing on 
setting the file's write permission, the context menu on the file displays edit option, but unedit option 
is grayed out.  I'm not sure which way I'd prefer.  But since file is technically locked for edit from cvs 
point of view, I would think I should get unedit instead of edit, since running cvs edit on that file will 
only result in the cvs editor window popping up.

FWIW, I tried this test with the source build for AMD 64.  I also added a few debug statements to 
EclipseFile.java and some others while building it, and I verified that after setReadOnly is called from 
the edit method, the file still remains read only - readonly attribute if IFile is still set to true after 
setReadOnly(false) is called.  Not having the depth of knowledge in eclipse source code, my initial 
suspicion is that issue exists in the JNI level for amd 64 while the issue is on higher level for Mac 
version.

And just one additional information i just thought of, in the previous 3.0 build versions for mac (prior 
to m8), extssh protocol did work properly for both cvs edit notify and file permission.  however, ext 
protocol always displayed the same behavior that the current builds of eclipse is displaying.  I don't 
know if this means anything.

Additional notes after some more debugging on amd 64, the platform is not able to load the core jni 
library as it fails on initialization of CoreFileSystemLibrary.java, and hasNative stays false, which forces 
the setReadOnly method of CoreFileSystemLibrary.java to bypass internalSetReadOnlyW call and just 
return false.

I'm going to submit a separate bug report for this.

I might be able to debug this on Mac too, though now I am 100% positive they are different issues.

This is not an issue with CVS. We just use the API provided by Core to set and 
clear the read-only bit. Moving to Core.

not sure if this is still the bug id to use for the issue with os x.

no more amd 64 issue.  it's handled in bug 12358.

on osx, what seems to be happening is when you edit a file that still marked as unedited (with 
immutable bit and readonly bit), it fires up cvs edit command but still remains read only.  i close the file 
that i just tried to edit, reopen it and try editing it again, then it pops up the cvs editors window saying 
it's already checked out by me, then it unsets the read only bit.  i confirmed this with my coworker as 
well.   thought this might be useful.

Ok, I looked at this with MichaelV and we verified that this is not a Team problem. Here are simple 
steps to show the underlying problem:

1) Create a project
2) Create a file in the project (any file, say "foo.txt")
3) Open (Eclipse) properties dialog for file, and check "Read only".
4) Close dialog
5) Re-open properties dialog; file is (correctly) marked read only
6) Uncheck read only
7) Close dialog
8) Use Mac "Get Info" dialog to verify that file is now not read only
9) Open properties dialog
10) Notice that read only is _still_checked_
11) Uncheck the read only check box (again)
12) Close and re-open properties dialog
13) Notice that this time the read only check box _is_not_checked_.

From looking at the code quickly, it seems like on the Mac, after the first IResource.setReadOnly(true) 
call is made IResource.getReadOnly() still returns false. However, the setReadOnly(true) call *did* 
succeed, and calling setReadOnly(true) a second time, leaves it in a state that getReadOnly() will return 
true.

Assigning to Andre, since I believe this is a problem in the Mac C natives.

A chmod call fails after immutable flag has been set.
Fix is to swap the order of chmod and chflags calls when readOnly state is cleared.

Created an attachment (id=11865)
patch for core.c

DJ to fix the bug in Resources.setReadOnly described in Comment  #23 and make sure that the patch 
is released.
Let me know if you want me to release the binary for Mac.

Andre, please release the changes to the library. 

Since IResource#setReadOnly doesn't have a return value or throw an exception,
we only have a couple of choices:
1). throw an unchecked exception
2). log a message every time
3). log a message the first time

If the user is running on a platform in which we don't ship our natives and they
try to make a read-only file read-write, they will come across this situation
everytime. I will update the code in Resource#setReadOnly to silently log a
message the first time it happens.
Fix and binary released.

Released changes to Resource#setReadOnly.
Will be included in today's noon build.
